subject: [Slashdot] Stories for 2007-04-10
body:
======================================================================
Open source and Linux from HP
>From nine consecutive years of Linux market leadership to countless
community outreach programs, HP has proven solutions you can value, on a
next generation, highly-efficient BladeSystem platform ideal for Linux,
with the approach, experience, and customer commitment you can trust.
http://showcase.linux.com/hpos.tmp
======================================================================

Slashdot Daily Newsletter

In this issue:
    * Satellites Mating Via Robotic Arm
    * Hacker Replaces iPod HDD With Flash Memory
    * Debian 4.0 'Etch' Released
    * SCO Relies On IBM-donated Servers With Groklaw
    * Some Blu-Ray, HD DVD Discs Sell Only 200 Copies
    * You Played Violent Games - Why Can't Your Kids?
    * P2P Program to Match Files to Product Origin
    * Bad Math Causes Explosion at CERN Collider
    * Revolution, Flashmobs and Brain Implants in 2035
    * Apple TV "Barely Watchable"
    * Taxes, Second Life and Warcraft

    * Xbox Spring Update To Offer Codecs, MSN Messenger

+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Satellites Mating Via Robotic Arm                                  |
|   from the that's-one-way-to-do-it dept.                           |
|   posted by Zonk on Sunday April 08, @21:27 (Robotics)             |
|   http://hardware.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/0039217     |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Roland Piquepaille writes "The launch of the Orbital Express mission,
with its two satellites ASTRO and NextSat, the first one servicing the
other, was widely covered a month ago. But what is happening in space
now? In '[1]Robotic satellite servicer rehearsal underway in orbit,'
Spaceflight Now reports about the progress done. A week ago, the two
satellites were able to link to each other to operate the first transfer
of hydrazine fuel from ASTRO's propellant tanks into NextSat. This
weekend, ASTRO's ten-foot-long robotic arm is going to be used to move
objects to NextSat. But what does it mean for international satellite
operators when they need help with their space birds? Will they use a
system designed for U.S.'s DARPA? "

Discuss this story at:
    http://hardware.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/0039217

Links:
    0. http://www.primidi.com/
    1. http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n0704/03orbitalexpress/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Hacker Replaces iPod HDD With Flash Memory                         |
|   from the and-now-i-can-drop-it dept.                             |
|   posted by Zonk on Sunday April 08, @23:45 (Hardware Hacking)     |
|   http://apple.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/0329204        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

Via [0]a Wired Blog, an anonymous reader wrote with a link to a post on
the Geek Technique website. There, post author Mark Hoekstra details
[1]how to replace an iPod's HDD with flash memory. It's not an
inexpensive procedure, as 16 Gigs of flash memory is still a mite
expensive, and the post is not a 'how-to'. Just the same, the project
took painstaking work and is well worth recognizing. "I guess I can say I
found ways of eliminating almost every hard drive out of almost every
hard drive based iPod thereby eliminating all moving parts. The only one
left is the iPod video which would only need a slightly different
adapter. But next to that I've got a gut feeling that one's being
upgraded to flash memory by Apple themselves any time soon."

Discuss this story at:
    http://apple.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/0329204

Links:
    0. http://blog.wired.com/gadgets/2007/04/geek_technique_.html
    1. http://geektechnique.org/projectlab/767/put-flash-memory-into-almost-any-ipod


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Debian 4.0 'Etch' Released                                         |
|   from the etch-up-me-harties dept.                                |
|   posted by Zonk on Monday April 09, @01:20 (Debian)               |
|   http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/0332252        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "Earlier today we discussed the possibility
that [0]Debian Etch might be released soon. Well, according to
[1]debian.org, it has already happened. [2]Etch has been released: 'The
Debian Project is pleased to announce [3]the official release of Debian
GNU/Linux version 4.0, codenamed etch, after 21 months of constant
development. Debian GNU/Linux is a free operating system which supports a
total of eleven processor architectures and includes the KDE, GNOME and
Xfce desktop environments. It also features cryptographic software and
compatibility with the FHS v2.3 and software developed for version 3.1 of
the LSB.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://linux.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/0332252

Links:
    0. http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/08/017241&tid=90
    1. http://debian.org/
    2. http://www.debian.org/News/2007/20070408
    3. http://cdimage.debian.org/debian-cd/4.0_r0/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| SCO Relies On IBM-donated Servers With Groklaw                     |
|   from the come-together-right-now dept.                           |
|   posted by Zonk on Monday April 09, @03:11 (IBM)                  |
|   http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/0639232        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

Technician writes "It appears that [0]SCO and Groklaw have the exact same
tie to IBM: the ibiblio service. 'An eagle-eyed Groklaw ninja, sk43, has
spotted an ftp site where you can get binary copies of Linux libraries
needed by SCO's OpenServer and UnixWare customers who use lxrun. But you
can't get the source code from that sco.com ftp site. SCO directs their
customers to .... sunsite.unc.edu. Why bless my stars, sunsite.unc.edu is
the old name for what is now ibiblio!'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://linux.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/0639232

Links:
    0. http://www.groklaw.net/article.php?story=20070407221422994


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Some Blu-Ray, HD DVD Discs Sell Only 200 Copies                    |
|   from the i-think-that's-called-weak-sauce dept.                  |
|   posted by Zonk on Monday April 09, @05:12 (Media)                |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/0639258              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "Much has been made of the strong sales for
some recent high-def disc releases (such as [0]'Casino Royale' on Blu-ray),
but a new Sony research report reveals some [1]startlingly low sales
numbers for other titles released on the next-gen formats. When disc
sales of under 1000 can land you on a weekly best-sellers list, you know
your format is in its infancy."

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/0639258

Links:
    0. http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/03/27/161243&tid=188
    1. http://www.highdefdigest.com/news/show/564


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| You Played Violent Games - Why Can't Your Kids?                    |
|   from the time-to-sit-your-kid-down-to-have-the-frags-and-camping-|
|   posted by Zonk on Monday April 09, @07:21 (Games)                |
|   http://ask.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/0649209          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes: "On the Wired site, Clive Thompson has up an
article that points out a sobering truth: [0]gamers are getting older.
Folks who grew up playing videogames like Doom and Quake are now facing
parental decisions with their own kids regarding appropriate content.
Thompson cites well known gamer dads like Kotaku's Brian Crecente,
discussing some of the approaches folks educated in gaming take with
their own offspring: '"Everybody knows, as an adult, that the world is
not always a nice place," Crecente told me. "But I don't want him to know
that yet. I want him to have a childhood." So he disallows games with
"realistic" combat, like World War II titles, or Resistance: Fall of Man,
but permits highly cartoony shooting, like Starfox on the Nintendo DS --
since he regards it as essentially as abstract as playing cops and
robbers with your fingers as guns.' Where do you think gamer parents
should draw the line? If you have kids, what approach are you taking to
introducing them to gaming? How old is 'old enough' to start fragging?"

Discuss this story at:
    http://ask.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/0649209

Links:
    0. http://www.wired.com/gaming/virtualworlds/commentary/games/2007/04/gamesfrontiers_0409


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| P2P Program to Match Files to Product Origin                       |
|   from the gonna-be-a-slow-day dept.                               |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @08:29 (Software)         |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1210213              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Keiron Waites writes "A program to [1]match p2p downloads with the
original products they came from has been released. [2]ShareMonkey is
free software for Microsoft Windows, with an additional plugin for the
Shareaza p2p application. ShareMonkey lets you right click on a file and
choose "Where is this file from?", which will direct you to a listing of
products that carry the file. ShareMonkey is a service for those p2p
users that download copyrighted files in a "try before you buy" capacity
and is an attempt to bridge the gap between copyright infringement and
subsequent purchasing of a product."

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1210213

Links:
    0. mailto:keiron@leadbullet.net
    1. http://www.leadbullet.net/wp-content/uploads/2007/04/leadbullet_press_release.pdf
    2. http://www.sharemonkey.com/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Bad Math Causes Explosion at CERN Collider                         |
|   from the allright-which-of-you-got-the-A dept.                   |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @09:09 (Science)          |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1240249      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]javipas writes "The Large Hadron Collider at the CERN has suffered a
big explosion deep inside that has caused a leak of hellium gas and the
quick evacuation of everyone working there. The reason: [1]a mathematical
mistake that affected the design of the giant superconductive magnets
made by Fermilab. Now the company will have to repair and upgrade the 24
magnets that are installed on the 27 km. circunference of one of the most
important research centers on Earth." This story might seem [2]strangely
familiar to you.

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1240249

Links:
    0. http://www.javipas.com/
    1. http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article1626728.ece
    2. http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/03/31/1352243&tid=99


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Revolution, Flashmobs and Brain Implants in 2035                   |
|   from the some-a-lot-sooner-than-others dept.                     |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @09:45 (Sci-Fi)           |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1247223              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

siddesu writes "Marxist revolution, WMDs, flashmobs and other sci-fi
items are [0]coming soon in a country near you, according to the UK
Ministry of Defence. 'Information chips implanted in the brain.
Electromagnetic pulse weapons. The middle classes becoming revolutionary,
taking on the role of Marx's proletariat. The population of countries in
the Middle East increasing by 132%, while Europe's drops as fertility
falls. "Flashmobs" \u2014 groups rapidly mobilised by criminal gangs or
terrorists groups. This is the world in 30 years' time envisaged by a
Ministry of Defence team responsible for painting a picture of the
"future strategic context" likely to face Britain's armed forces.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1247223

Links:
    0. http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/story/0,,2053020,00.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Apple TV "Barely Watchable"                                        |
|   from the so-was-baywatch dept.                                   |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @10:20 (Media (Apple))    |
|   http://apple.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1412223        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

lpangelrob writes "Peter Svensson of the Associated Press [0]reviews the
Apple TV, and comes away less than impressed.While the Apple TV gets
solid marks for "a very iPod-like interface, commendably clear and easy
to use", the Apple TV experience falls apart on an HD television. The
reviewer notes that "videos from Apple's online iTunes store look
horrible on an HDTV set. The movies and TV shows have the same nominal
resolution as DVDs, but look much blurrier, approaching the look of
standard-definition broadcast TV.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://apple.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1412223

Links:
    0. http://www.theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070406/APF/704063839


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Taxes, Second Life and Warcraft                                    |
|   from the get-on-the-ype-train dept.                              |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @11:00 (Role Playing (Game|
|   http://games.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1417254        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader wrote in to say that there is "...a new law review
article that explores the [0]tax treatment of players in Second Life and
World of Warcraft. The bottom line is that commercial activity that
occurs in virtual worlds should be taxed the same as in the real world.
But purely personal activity within virtual worlds should not be taxed."

Discuss this story at:
    http://games.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1417254

Links:
    0. http://taxprof.typepad.com/taxprof_blog/2007/04/tax_treatment_o.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Learn How UNIX Multitasks                                          |
|   from the i-can't-even-unitask-this-morning dept.                 |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @11:49 (Unix)             |
|   http://developers.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1539255   |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]BlueVoodoo writes "On UNIX systems, each system and end-user task is
contained within a process. Learn how to [1]control processes and use a
number of commands to peer into your system."

Discuss this story at:
    http://developers.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1539255

Links:
    0. mailto:doccalypso@hotmail.com
    1. http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/aix/library/au-speakingunix8/?ca=dgr-lnxw01speakunix8


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Two Worm "Families" Make Up Most Botnets                           |
|   from the why-can't-they-fight-eachother-instead-of-us dept.      |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @12:32 (Worms)            |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1553205           |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

JMoon writes "HNS has an article about the Sdbot and Gaobot families
which [0]are responsible for most botnets worldwide. These two families
were responsible for 80 percent of detections related to bots during the
first quarter of 2007. Other culprits, although on a much lesser scale,
included Oscarbot, IRCbot or RXbot."

Discuss this story at:
    http://it.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1553205

Links:
    0. http://www.net-security.org/virus_news.php?id=777


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Xbox Spring Update To Offer Codecs, MSN Messenger                  |
|   from the might-be-able-to-retire-my-xbox-180 dept.               |
|   posted by CmdrTaco on Monday April 09, @13:19 (XBox (Games))     |
|   http://games.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/162212         |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]adachan writes "It seems that Microsoft has decided to add Xvid
playback into the upcoming [1]Spring Xbox 360 dashboard update. Xbox.com
has a list of all the upcoming enhancements to the dash. The playback of
video using H.264 and mpeg4 codecs seems to be the biggest news for those
using the system as a media extender. If this is indeed true, my Xbox
Media Center will be used less and less." Update: 04/09 17:29 GMT by [2]Z
: MSN Messenger is kinda interesting as well. Several sites are reporting
that [3]instant messenging is being added to the Xbox Live experience,
with a [4]USB keyboard controller attachment to be offered sometime in
the near future.

Discuss this story at:
    http://games.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/162212

Links:
    0. http://www.adamnoah.com/
    1. http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/news/2007/0408-im.htm
    2. http://slashdot.org/~Zonk/
    3. http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=13440
    4. http://www.1up.com/do/newsStory?cId=3158577


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Combined Hovercraft and Helicopter                                 |
|   from the m.a.s.k. dept.                                          |
|   posted by samzenpus on Monday April 09, @14:05 (Science)         |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1723218      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "Has British engineer Geoff Hatton brought us
the best of two worlds with his [0]UFO-looking machine? The US military
thinks so and are investing in it. The design is sturdy (as opposed to a
helicopter) and can fly high (as opposed to a hovercraft). It is based on
the [1]Coanda Effect."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1723218

Links:
    0. http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/technology/technology.html?in_article_id=447317
    1. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coanda_Effect


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| U.S. Billionaire Heads to Space Station                            |
|   from the now-that's-an-expensive-hotel dept.                     |
|   posted by samzenpus on Monday April 09, @14:56 (Space)           |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1740222      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

TurnAround writes "According to an International Business Times article,
a Russian rocket carrying the American billionaire who helped develop
Microsoft Word roared into the night skies over Kazakhstan Saturday,
sending [0]Charles Simonyi and two cosmonauts soaring into orbit on a
two-day journey to the international space station. Climbing on a column
of smoke and fire into the clouds over the bleak steppes, the Soyuz
TMA-10 capsule lifted off at 11:31 p.m. local time, casting an orange
glow over the Baikonur cosmodrome and dozens of officials and
well-wishers watching from about a mile away."

Discuss this story at:
    http://science.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1740222

Links:
    0. http://ibtimes.com/apnews/20070408/russia-space.htm


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| MySQL Pocket Reference                                             |
|   from the in-the-palm-of-your-hand dept.                          |
|   posted by samzenpus on Monday April 09, @15:42 (Book Reviews)    |
|   http://books.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1447220        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]Michael J. Ross writes "MySQL database administrators and developers
have several options for MySQL reference sources, though naturally none
of them are ideal in all situations. The online MySQL documentation is
extensive, but the most commonly needed nuggets are buried in its
necessarily exhaustive contents. Third-party MySQL reference books can
winnow out some of the rarely-used minutia, but they still encompass
hundreds of pages, reflecting the complexity of the subject. For quickly
looking up the most frequently used command syntax and other details, a
MySQL user would usually be best served by a much more compact book, such
as MySQL Pocket Reference." Read below for the rest of Michael's review.

This story continues at:
    http://books.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1447220

Discuss this story at:
    http://books.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1447220

Links:
    0. http://www.ross.ws/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Birthplace of Silicon Valley in Shambles                           |
|   from the preserving-the-past dept.                               |
|   posted by samzenpus on Monday April 09, @16:31 (IT)              |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/1754233           |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

CowTipperGore writes "Founded by William Shockley in the mid-50s,
[0]Shockley Semiconductor Lab is generally credited with starting the
Silicon Valley boom. When he was unable to lure his former Bell Labs
coworkers to join him, he filled his ranks with the best and brightest
engineering school grads, including Zombie Moore and others who later
went on to form Fairchild Semiconductor and Intel. The building at 391
San Antonio Road, Mountain View, California, is the original site of the
company but, unlike the [1]HP Garage, this building has received little
protection or preservation. It recently housed a fruit stand, where
visitors could find a small display about Shockley above baskets of
fruit. [2]The fruit stand is now closed, leaving the future of the
building in the air."

Discuss this story at:
    http://it.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/1754233

Links:
    0. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shockley_Semiconductor_Laboratory
    1. http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/abouthp/histnfacts/garage/
    2. http://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/04/09/shockley_fruit_closed/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| 100 Million iPods                                                  |
|   from the that's-a-lot-of-music dept.                             |
|   posted by samzenpus on Monday April 09, @17:27 (Media (Apple))   |
|   http://apple.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/181242         |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

prelelat writes "I find it somewhat hard to believe but this story over
at PC world, indicates that [0]the iPod has sold over 100 million units.
It also asks how many are broken and replaced which makes me believe the
number may be more accurate."

Discuss this story at:
    http://apple.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/181242

Links:
    0. http://blogs.pcworld.com/techlog/archives/004048.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Google Website Optimizer                                           |
|   from the google-google-google dept.                              |
|   posted by samzenpus on Monday April 09, @18:12 (Google)          |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/192212            |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]compuglot writes "Google has released the third leg of the stool in
its quest to dominate online marketing. [1]Google Website Optimizer is a
multivariate testing application that allows users to test elements and
combinations of elements in a website or landing page. The goal is
[2]increased conversions, and of course AdWords market share."

Discuss this story at:
    http://it.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/192212

Links:
    0. mailto:jhorsager@gmail.com
    1. http://services.google.com/websiteoptimizer/
    2. http://www.marketingpilgrim.com/2007/04/increase-conversion-rates-with-the-google-website-optimizer.html


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Judge Gives Intel More Time To Find Missing E-mail                 |
|   from the look-hard dept.                                         |
|   posted by samzenpus on Monday April 09, @19:03 (Intel)           |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/2011215          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]narramissic writes "ITworld is reporting that Intel has until April 17
(7 days more than the original deadline of April 10) to 'explain to a
judge [1]why it lost e-mail records that could provide proof that the
chip maker used anticompetitive practices as alleged by Advanced Micro
Devices Inc. (AMD).' According to an order from Vincent Poppiti, the
special master hearing negotiations of the case, the court is looking for
an accounting of Intel's document preservation problems and a proposal
for a better solution for archiving future records."

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/2011215

Links:
    0. http://www.itworld.com/
    1. http://www.itworld.com/Man/2699/070409judgeintel/


+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Google Admits to Using Sohu Database                               |
|   from the cut-and-paste dept.                                     |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Monday April 09, @19:46 (Google)         |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/09/2259230          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]prostoalex writes "A few days ago a Chinese company, Sohu.com,
[1]alleged Google improperly tapped its database for its Pinyin IME
product, stirring controversy on whether two databases were similar just
due to normal research process. Today [2]Google admitted that its new
product for Chinese market 'was built leveraging some non-Google database
resources.' 'The dictionaries used with both software from Google and
Sohu shared several common mistakes, where Chinese characters were
matched with the wrong Pinyin equivalents. In addition, both dictionaries
listed the names of engineers who had developed Sohu's Sogou Pinyin
IME.'"

Discuss this story at:
    http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/04/09/2259230

Links:
    0. http://www.moskalyuk.com/blog
    1. http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/04/08/1824210&tid=217
    2. http://www.pcworld.com/article/id,130502-c,copyright/article.html
